reading_comprehensions.title: The Busy Honeybee
reading_comprehensions.paragraph: Honeybees are important insects that live in colonies. They help plants grow by carrying pollen from one flower to another. Honeybees also make honey, which people use as food. A colony has a queen bee, worker bees, and drones, each with a special role.

reading_comprehensions.title: The Rainforest Adventure
reading_comprehensions.paragraph: Rainforests are thick forests with many tall trees and lots of rain. They are home to millions of different animals and plants. Many colorful birds like parrots live in the trees. Monkeys swing from branch to branch looking for fruit to eat. The rainforest floor is dark because the thick leaves above block most sunlight.

reading_comprehensions.title: My Pet Dog Max
reading_comprehensions.paragraph: Max is my golden retriever dog. He has soft, yellow fur and brown eyes. Every morning, Max wakes me up by licking my face. He loves to play fetch with his red ball in the backyard. Max is very friendly and always wags his tail when he sees visitors. At night, he sleeps on a soft bed next to mine.

reading_comprehensions.title: The School Library
reading_comprehensions.paragraph: Our school library is a quiet place where students come to read and study. Mrs. Johnson, the librarian, helps us find books we need. The library has different sections: fiction books with made-up stories, non-fiction books with real facts, and a computer section for research. Students must whisper and return books on time. The library also has comfortable reading corners with soft chairs and good lighting.

reading_comprehensions.title: The Water Cycle
reading_comprehensions.paragraph: The water cycle is how water moves around our planet. First, the sun heats water in oceans, rivers, and lakes, turning it into invisible water vapor that rises into the sky. This process is called evaporation. High in the sky, the water vapor cools down and forms tiny droplets that create clouds. This is called condensation. When the clouds become heavy with water, the droplets fall back to Earth as rain or snow. This is called precipitation. The water then flows back to rivers and oceans, and the cycle starts again.
